item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 18
item.description: A gun control compromise fails in the U.S. Senate; children in Greece are going hungry; reviving the Garden of Eden; and confronting the hazards of judo.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Michalis Petrakis, who is jobless and whose son Pantelis has been going to school hungry, shows his nearly empty refrigerator.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 18
item.description: A protest in Ahmedabad against a power tariff hike by the Gujarat government.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Women took to the streets in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, protesting a recent power tariff hike by the state government.

item.title: Facing Arrest, Musharraf Flees Pakistani Courtroom
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, a former military leader, made a dramatic escape after a judge revoked his bail over a case dating to his years in power.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's former president, left the High Court in Islamabad on Thursday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: New Zealand Leads Way on Same-Sex Marriage in Asia-Pacific
item.description: As New Zealand becomes a trend-setter in the Asia-Pacific region by legalizing same-sex marriage, nations like Vietnam and Thailand are also exploring it.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Celebrations begin in Auckland as the New Zealand parliament voted to legalize same-sex marriage.

item.title: India Ink: Goofus and Gallant Come to India
item.description: Indian versions of the American children’s magazine Highlights unveiled in New Delhi on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By HEATHER TIMMONS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Bahrain F1 Event Goes Ahead Despite Human Rights Protests
item.description: Race organizers have once again rejected appeals to cancel the Bahrain Grand Prix, an event demonstrators plan to use to highlight continuing repression in the Arabian Gulf kingdom.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Bahraini protestors sprayed anti-Formula One graffiti last Friday.

item.title: India Ink: Ammonium Nitrate Used in Bangalore Blast, Police Say
item.description: No connection between Boston bombings and Bangalore blast, Indian home minister says.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: An official inspecting the motorcycle that was used in the blast in Malleshwaram in Bangalore, Karnataka, on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: Does Nitish Kumar Need the B.J.P.?
item.description: Challenging Gujarat chief minister’s credentials for the prime ministerial post, Bihar’s chief minster has upset coalition allies.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Nitish Kumar, chief minister of Bihar, during an interview in Patna, Bihar, on Jan. 9, 2012.

item.title: South Korean Police Say Spy Service Tried to Influence Election
item.description: The authorities stopped short of accusing agents of violating the country’s election law, a decision the opposition party called a whitewash.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Emirates Seize Qaeda Supporters
item.description: The authorities in the United Arab Emirates said on Thursday they had arrested seven members of a “terrorist cell” accused of plotting attacks in the Emirates and its neighbors.
item.dc:creator: By HALA DROUBI

item.title: French Court Orders Lagarde to Appear in Tapie Case
item.description: Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, has been summoned to a hearing next month on her handling of a financial scandal when she was the French finance minister.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Tale of China’s Leader in a Taxicab Is Retracted
item.description: A Hong Kong newspaper admits that a story that was almost too good to be true was in fact not.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Investigators Search for Origin of Flu Strain
item.description: As investigators looked at the possibility of human-to-human transmission, there was mounting concern that the new virus may not originate in birds but in other animals and in environmental sources.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: North Korea Sets Conditions for Return to Talks
item.description: North Korea on Thursday demanded the lifting of United Nations sanctions and an end to joint American-South Korean military exercises as preconditions for starting dialogue.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Tesco to Pay Dearly to Leave United States
item.description: The British chain, which grossly misjudged American consumer habits, said it would cost $1.8 billion to quit the U.S. market.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA WERDIGIER

item.title: India Ink: India’s Tata Group Maps U.S. Expansion
item.description: Better known for outsourcing jobs to India, Tata is ramping up in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: By SHIVANI VORA
item.media:description: Ratan Tata, former Tata Group chairman, left, at the India launch of Jaguar Land Rover with Phil Popham, managing director of Land Rover in Mumbai, Maharashtra on June 28, 2009.

item.title: Key Obama Officials Differ on Syria in Testimony
item.description: The differing assessments came as the White House was considering what next steps to take in a conflict that has killed more than 70,000 and defied resolution.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: A Syrian boy salvaged items from a garbage dump on Wednesday in the war-ravaged northern Syrian city of Aleppo. The war there has killed more than 70,000.

item.title: Assad Frames Syrian Struggle as Him Against Western Colonizers
item.description: In an interview conducted on Syria’s Independence Day, President Bashar al-Assad reveals that his views on the country’s civil war have only hardened.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA

item.title: No Deal Yet in Serbia and Kosovo Talks to Ease Tensions
item.description: The countries have agreed on the broad principle that Serbs in a Serbian-majority area in northern Kosovo would gain more powers and tacitly recognize Kosovo’s government.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A resident of the ethnically divided town of Mitrovica in Kosovo, which may grant more autonomy to majority Serbs in the north.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Honduras: Attorney General Is Suspended
item.description: Saying it was frustrated with some of the worst criminal violence in the world, the Honduran congress suspended the attorney general and his assistant.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Mubarak to Be Moved to Prison
item.description: Egypt’s chief prosecutor on Wednesday ordered the transfer of former President Hosni Mubarak from a Cairo military hospital back to prison.
item.dc:creator: By MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: World Briefing | South Pacific: New Zealand: Gay Marriage Bill Passes
item.description: Parliament on Wednesday voted 77 to 44 to legalize same-sex marriage, making New Zealand the 13th nation in the world and the first in the Asia-Pacific region to allow gay couples to marry.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Europeans Step Toward Easing Syrian Oil Exports
item.description: European Union members reached a preliminary agreement as part of an effort to make opposition-held areas self-sufficient, diplomats said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Fighters with the Free Syrian Army taking positions on the roof of a building in the eastern city of Deir al-Zour.

item.title: Key Obama Officials Differ on Syria in Testimony
item.description: The differing assessments came as the White House was considering what next steps to take in a conflict that has killed more than 70,000 and defied resolution.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: A Syrian boy salvaged items from a garbage dump on Wednesday in the war-ravaged northern Syrian city of Aleppo. The war there has killed more than 70,000.

item.title: National Briefing | Washington: Court Declines to Rule in Wikileaks Complaint
item.description: A military appeals court on Wednesday declined to rule on a lawsuit seeking greater access for journalists to court filings and proceedings in the criminal case against Pfc. Bradley Manning.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
